fields.value: Replication Data for: Blood Pressure and Arterial Stiffness in Kenyan Adolescents With α+Thalassemia

authorAffiliation.value: KEMRI-Wellcome Trust Research Programme, Kilifi Kenya

dsDescriptionValue.value:
Background recent studies have discovered that a_globin is expressed in blood vessel walls where it plays a role in regulating vascular tone. We tested the hypothesis that blood pressure (BP) might differ between normal individuals and those with alpha thalassemia, in whom the production of alpha globin is reduced.

The related study - Shinikizo la Damu 2 (ShinDa2) - was conducted in Nairobi, Kenya, among 938 adolescents aged 11 to 17 years. Twenty‐four‐hour ambulatory BP monitoring and arterial stiffness measurements were performed using an arteriograph device. We genotyped for α+thalassemia by polymerase chain reaction. Complete data for analysis were available for 623 subjects; 223 (36%) were heterozygous (−α/αα) and 47 (8%) were homozygous (−α/−α) for α+thalassemia whereas the remaining 353 (55%) were normal (αα/αα). Mean 24‐hour systolic BP ±SD was 118±12 mm Hg in αα/αα, 117±11 mm Hg in −α/αα, and 118±11 mm Hg in −α/−α subjects, respectively. Mean 24‐hour diastolic BP ±SD in these groups was 64±8, 63±7, and 65±8 mm Hg, respectively. Mean pulse wave velocity (PWV)±SD was 7±0.8, 7±0.8, and 7±0.7 ms−1, respectively. No differences were observed in PWV and any of the 24‐hour ambulatory BP monitoring‐derived measures between those with and without α+thalassemia.

publicationCitation.value: Etyang, A.O., Khayeka‐Wandabwa, C., Kapesa, S., Muthumbi, E., Odipo, E., Wamukoya, M., Ngomi, N., Haregu, T., Kyobutungi, C., Tendwa, M. and Makale, J., 2017. Blood Pressure and Arterial Stiffness in Kenyan Adolescents With α+ Thalassemia. Journal of the American Heart Association, 6(4), p.e005613.
